title: Thinking with Mold: Metabolizing the Planet in a Changing Climate
excerpt: I'm a social anthropologist, not a biologist or mycologist. But like everyone else on planet earth, I live with those environmentally ubiquitous, filamentous fungi that are commonly referred to in English as mold[cite: 4, 5]. [cite_start]Over the past five years, as I have been researching how people live with, adapt to, and build solutions to weather patterns that are attributable to rising greenhouse-gas emissions, I have come to understand that mold is everywhere[cite: 10]. [cite_start]Across North America and Europe, mold is having a cultural moment, appearing in everything from time-lapse photography and haute cuisine to hit musicals and satirical television[cite: 12, 13, 14, 16, 17]. [cite_start]Yet, mold has emerged as a visceral, cross-cultural signifier of planetary climate change[cite: 20]. [cite_start]This chapter explores the 'metabolic rift' of industrial capitalism and the duel register of Aspergillus moldsâ€”at once culturally constructed as harmful 'feral' threats requiring control and scientifically hailed as beneficial components of 'microbial metal factories' for the biotech economy[cite: 51, 56, 149, 153, 156].
